text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

GUEST SPEAKER: The first
project was in the quarry,
as Jen explained.

My design proposal--
I found a kind

of a sloping rock area that had
many little nooks and crannies

of different sizes for people
to gather in different amount--

like different
numbers of people.

And I kind of just
covered them appropriately

to what I thought their
use would best be.

I showed just kind of a 3D
plan in a way, and section.
That project I was having fun.

It was really quick project,
and it ended up just
being kind of fun.

The second project, I
got a rooftop design
in one corner of the North End.

And it was kind
of a key position.

I watched over everybody--
all the other people
in the North End.

So I wanted to take advantage
of that and do my duty

and get kind of high up
and look out over everyone.

And I had one wall kind
of blocking my view
of the city-- the other side.

And so I just rose up
above that as well.

And that was kind an
interesting project,

because we had to
look at where we
were going to be in 10 years.

And so I imagined myself married
and probably an architect.

And it was just
kind of interesting.

I like the way Jen
kind of presented it

and make sure you
kind of think ahead.

And lost a lot of weight
I see on the roof.
Yeah.
Yes.

All right, and then a third
project was more in depth.

We had at least twice
the time for this,

so we started out with
the classic junk model
or found objects model.

He wanted us to
get an idea of form

and not necessarily use,
like just play with the junk
and see what comes out of it.

And this was the
funnest project for me.

A lot of people
struggled with it,

and they love building
regular models.
And this is it for me.
This is amazing.
I love it.

So I just kind of
played with junk

and thought about people
are going to be coming.

Main traffic from the North
End' is coming in here,

and my main idea was just
to attract people in.
And so I made--
I found this on the side.
And so I had to put it in there.
That's my attention getter--
official name.

So I had the idea
of a butterfly.

Like in Victoria, BC,
I went into this--
I guess it was a zoo.
Or it wasn't even a zoo.

There were a few animals around,
but their main attraction

was this huge
butterfly conservatory.

And you just walk
in there, and you're

surrounded by butterflies, and
you can touch them or whatever.

And it's just kind
of like you're just--
I had a great feeling about it.

I can't really
describe the feeling,

but I want to go back there,
and I haven't gone back yet.

But anyway, I wanted
to capture that.

I wanted to bring nature
into the North End.

That was kind of the
goal of the project,
and it was interesting.
It was fun.
But I did get a chance to go--

during Thanksgiving I
went down to New York,

and just by chance I went to
see a friend's dad's exhibit

in the Museum of
Natural History.

And I saw this thing, and
it just said butterflies.

And I was like hey, I'm doing
a project on butterflies,

so I might as well
go check it out.

And it turned out to be
exactly what I was doing.

There's just some
images from it,

and it's exactly
how I imagined it.

So it was kind of
cool just to see it.

From this junk model, we moved
into kind of the block model.

I tried to be a
little more realistic,
and I kind of messed up.

I didn't translate
it right, basically.
I was trying to turn--

I like that one a lot
better than this one,

and it took me a little
while to figure it out.

It's just different sizes and
relationships between objects.

But I really liked what
was going on there,

and I wasn't able to
translate it into real form,

so I kind of struggled
with that a little bit.
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] model.
Is it curved--
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah, this.
AUDIENCE: forms an the like.

Did you find yourself
struggling to get back
to some of the [INAUDIBLE]?
GUEST SPEAKER: Oh yeah.
That was my biggest struggle.

Like I wanted to build
that basically and--

AUDIENCE: Is it modules
that [INAUDIBLE]

for constructing that, or
just the difficulty of having
the tools to build this?

GUEST SPEAKER: I think for some
reason the pre-made forms were
really easy.

You just kind of got
what they stood for

and put them in their
appropriate place.

And here you're
making everything,
and you can't really remake.

If I copied that exactly,
it wouldn't be the same.

It's a lot about
the texture as well.

I just really like
that model, and I was
struggling to put it into form.

Then we moved up to
an 1/8 scale model.
It's still up in studio.
In the hectic rush I forgot it.

This is the newer
1/8 scale model,

but that was my old
1/8 scale model.

And then what we do is
we cut a section of it.
Well, it was similar to this.

And we cut a section cut out of
it, and just take that chunk.

I cut right here, and so
this was-- and blew it up

to quarter scale, and just
kind of had fun with it.

So from that we
went on to drawing.

Like we just went straight to
drawing sessions and plans,

and then finally the
big eight-scale model.

I guess I'll talk a little bit
about what's going on here.

People are going to be
entering from the T-stop,

and I kind of wanted to
bring them in with a curve.
I don't know.

I wanted to bring
them into my space.

And so they come in,
and they see immediately

the butterfly conservatory,
and that interests them.

And the ramp is
kind of their way--

like it kind of signals
that that's the way
to get to the conservatory.
So they come up through--

there is a library on the
second and third floor.

It's kind of a smaller library,
more focused on nature.

There's already one
library in the North End,

so this one was just more,
I don't know, animals.

Like if kids come and
they want to learn more

about the butterflies,
where they come from,
then this is the place just to--
it's not a checkout library.

It's just you sit and read
out on-- there's a deck here

where you can sit
and look up through.

AUDIENCE: How does
one get to that level?
GUEST SPEAKER: Which--

AUDIENCE: This
second [INAUDIBLE]..
I see stairs coming up.

They're going to be
passing by this [INAUDIBLE]

going to the third
[INAUDIBLE] access.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.
The second level is the--

this is just the direct kind
of a path to the butterfly

conservatory, so that's what
people are going to see.

And then if they've
been here before

and they actually want
to go visit the library,

or they're done
visiting, then they

can take the elevator
down to the second floor
or the first floor.

And then also there's kind
of an IMAX-style theater
in the corner.

South is this direction, and
this is a very difficult site,

because there is almost
no natural sunlight.
Everything is blocked.

And there's this, the
perfect spot for a theater,

which is dark, and you
want it to be dark.

You don't want sun
shining in necessarily.

So this ended up being a
perfect spot for a theater,

whereas the library was
more open and sunny.

AUDIENCE: And do
you get to this--
the garden?

What's the relationship
with the garden
to the path's [INAUDIBLE]--

GUEST SPEAKER: The garden is
for people who have already

gone up, and there's going to
be a lot of tourists coming just
to see the butterflies.

And they're going to come and
do their thing and then leave.

But the garden is
more for the locals

to come and still enjoy
the butterflies without--

like they can come in and see
up through, and they can relax,
read books, whatever in the--

AUDIENCE: So you doubled
back, the way you came in?

You go out that way, so it's not
sort of this cycle that you go.

Because you indicate it's a
kind of a journey that goes up,
and you go through it.

But then you double back on
that journey and go down again.
Is that right?
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.

AUDIENCE: You didn't want the
journey to continue and go down
into the garden.

I'm just curious as to why
you think people come--
GUEST SPEAKER: You know what?
I honestly did not--

I never took it
through to that point.
AUDIENCE: OK.
AUDIENCE: What was your--

what was the piece
that you focused
on the most in this design?
What was the issue for you?

GUEST SPEAKER:
Well, obviously it

was the actual
structure of that.

That was like my main focus,
because when I blew it up

to quarter scale, it just made
it that much more interesting.

And I also focused
on the theater.
The library was kind of--
wasn't a primary focus.

AUDIENCE: Just what do you see
inside besides butterflies?
Presumably the plants in here--

GUEST SPEAKER: Yes,
plants and yeah.
AUDIENCE: Places to sit?

Is there anything like
that, or you walk around?

GUEST SPEAKER: It's
just kind of a walk.
It's not sitting.

Sitting is more
for the underneath.

I kind of imagine it-- even
before I visited here--

this is a lot smaller than what
I would build, but it was--

you just kind of go
through and circle through.

AUDIENCE: Because it's sort of a
habitat for butterflies, right?
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.

AUDIENCE: So they have their
place to land in a light?
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.

I tried to represent
in this section.
I didn't know how to really--

I didn't want to put
a lot of greenery,
and I just don't like--

AUDIENCE: So the green--
the glass floor then.
Could you talk about that?

GUEST SPEAKER: Mainly that
was for the experience
of the garden underneath--

for people to just kind
of look up and have

a cloud of
butterflies above them

and just be able
to appreciate that.

AUDIENCE: To what degree did
you have a program in mind when
you developed the junk?

GUEST SPEAKER: We had a basic
program of what kind of things
we wanted in the space.

And then we were told to
forget that and play it
with the objects.

AUDIENCE: As you
were developing that,

did you have a specific
program in mind
for each of the components?
GUEST SPEAKER: No.
The only thing--

I had this plane here, and
then when I put that over--
I was talking about--

well, I was either going to
do a brewery or a butterfly.
Those are my two main ideas.

And then once I put
this plane in here

and I found this
refractive paper,

I just kind of
draped it over there,

and I was like,
oh, it's perfect.

And so then I decided
to do butterflies.

It's just how it
worked in the space.

AUDIENCE: What I
find interesting
about this design process--

because this is a unique
design process in that you--

it starts with a
compositional process

where you've got pieces,
and you move them

around together in relation
to a context of form.

And you've come up with an
intriguing formal composition
in and of itself.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.

AUDIENCE: All right,
[INAUDIBLE] fascinating fun

and extremely exciting
look that can generate
a very interesting form.

It frees you up
a little bit Yeah

it was then the issue
is to translate that

into [INAUDIBLE] a habitable
and functioning place.

And the challenge there
is to analyze the model--

the kinds of territories
that have been made here

to define what
kind of activities

and applications each of those
territories most suggest.
I assume that's a--

GUEST SPEAKER: That
was kind of a-- yeah,

AUDIENCE: A couple of
things that sort of strike--
AUDIENCE: Yeah, keep going.

AUDIENCE: Pieces
that strike me--

one, you're starting now to
add a recession to-- you're

identifying with what I
sense is an identification

of the main program
elements, you know?

The conservatory up
high seeking the sun,

a theater you've described being
brought around [INAUDIBLE] kind

of place would be like a library
being put on that corner.

I think [INAUDIBLE] parts
underneath, all of which

I think are quite a
fascinating location.

I don't think I have
a difficult time--
the disposition of form.

The only piece I
think is the trickiest

is the space underneath
the conservatory.

In this particular
climate, I think that's a--

as a year round territory, it's
a very difficult kind of space.

But I think in
terms of function--

when one comes to
this point, one

should question now what
this climate and [INAUDIBLE]
have to do with habitation.

And I think then
you have to start

to let yourself make
modifications to address
those kinds of issues.

And it may have been about
trying to grab some of that,

thanks to your experience,
and let it be semi interior,

exterior [INAUDIBLE]
close it off and make
it warm in the winter and.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah, yeah.
No.

AUDIENCE: But the
one piece that I find

is this movement pattern that's
the most difficult to make it
with.
One is sitting to the--

one is getting to
the conservatory

and having to pass through
places that, in fact, probably

don't desire the main
rush of public activity.

Right now what's happened
is in making a public place,

you've made every
space somewhat equally

public by allowing the
circulation to flow through it.

know So I think
the hardest piece

for me is the ramp
finally coming and one,

bypassing the library-- the
main desk to the library,

scooting them up above
it, and asking people

to walk through
the library space

and finally find
the conservatory.

Because in many ways,
we're doing two things.

Were violating the library
and the library functions

and the ability to go
off to concentrate.

And two, we're asking
people to wander very far

away from the conservatory, and
that may be their destination.

We're asking [INAUDIBLE]
somewhere else

and get lost in the building,
and then finally come around

to find [INAUDIBLE] path
actually [INAUDIBLE]..

GUEST SPEAKER: Well,
my basic reasoning
for bringing it around--

I kind of wanted to give
a taste of what else

was there, because when you
have something like this,

the tendency is just to come
see that and you're done.

Like it's direct
movement, and I kind of

wanted to bring people
through the space,

give them an idea of just
what else goes on there.

AUDIENCE: It's a
wonderful notion.

I think that idea
is a solid one.

I think the execution of
it hurts the actual space

that you're trying to
introduce [INAUDIBLE]..

One is I think it
would be lovely to do

this in this procession
of the ramps and stairs--

to be able to
reach a place where

one could depart from that
ramp and go to a library

or from that ramp to see the
activities of the library
past it.

Or continue on to find
the convervatory--

one could get to the
conservatory fairly easily

and could get to each of the
levels with that main ramp.

I think using the
elevators device

to bring public to
each of the territories

is probably an unfortunate
mode of the vertical.

Those are the two
things that [INAUDIBLE]..

The third piece and
then I'll be done--

the theater and the notion
of entrance to a theater.
In many ways, if one is--

if the stage becomes
the place of focus

where an entire audience is
watching some activity that's

represented, a very
uncomfortable place

for people to enter
is onto that stage.

GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah, I
guess I was generally
thinking of just how--

the one theater that
I go to is Fenway.

And you come down the sides
and enter in the front,

and that's just kind of what I
was used to in a movie theater.
But this is the IMAX.
It's going to--

AUDIENCE: What helps
is to get people up
to the back, which [INAUDIBLE].

GUEST SPEAKER:
Yeah, there's also--

you can enter on
the second floor.

AUDIENCE: That place coming
into the second floor
was part of your main lobby.

You go to that
directly rather than--
GUEST SPEAKER: Gotcha.
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE].

So you can enter
the space, observe,

and get a sense of what's going
on without disturbing focus.

So all of these issues have
to do with the procession

and the way one
will pass through

and transition
between [INAUDIBLE]..
AUDIENCE: I had the same--

I guess my first
biggest reaction
relates to the movement again.

And it's some of the
same thing, saying

that it's sort of frustrating
to see this up there

and not knowing quite what the
journey is going to take you.

Because, in fact, you
want to get there,

but you're moving
against it, going
in the opposite direction.

So the feeling of
allowing you to somehow

have a wonderful journey that
might eventually reveal this

at different points--
and the glass floor

is also a point at
which you could actually
look up into something.

So maybe the journey
could take you

past the floor of
this thing, if you're

going to look up, rather than
just saying you look down

into it or you're
going to look up to it.
Make the journey part of your--

make the experience part of
it, and then you arrived.

And I agree with Alan
that perhaps when

you have those other spaces
like a library, which you want

people to get to, I could
imagine the libraries being
of actually butterflies--

just samples and examples
and a bit of history
and all that stuff--
the label.

That's something that you almost
want to see in these people.

You can have this choice
about do you see them first,

and then you find out more about
them because you're interested,

or do you find out
something about them
and then you see them?

Now, whether you give
the people the choice

or whether you take
them through a journey

I think it's something to
be worth thinking about.

And the relationship
then of that library

and those spaces to this
open space in the middle--

and I totally agree you've
got a very hard site.

It's a dark, north-facing
space, so maybe I

don't know what you do in terms
of trying to really bring light

and people into that
space, because it's

going to remain uninhabited
quite a lot of the time.

Maybe a few months in the summer
to get away from the heat,

it's this nice cool place in
[INAUDIBLE] and there's water.

GUEST SPEAKER: In my mind,
that's kind of the picture
that I was imagining.
And yeah, I--

AUDIENCE: The one that-- the
forms are kind of interesting.

But the one that I find I'm
not quite sure what it's doing

is that balcony
thing sticking out.

I find that kind of
frustrating, because it intrudes
in the space, and it doesn't--

I don't know what
you feel [INAUDIBLE]..
GUEST SPEAKER: I would never--

before the junk, I would
never have thought ever

to put anything like that,
because it just kind of looks
weird in a way, you know?
In a way.

And no, but I built
the junk model,

and I was completely
just going on form.

And I tried-- here,
the first translation.

I tried to get away
from it in a way--
didn't like it.

And for some reason,
I was just going

to say, all right, I'm
going to go with it
and see what it does.

And so I would usually never do
that, and so I just decided--

AUDIENCE: Well, I
mean, you can do.

It's just I'm just
curious about the space

and how it relates
to the other spaces.

AUDIENCE: First of all,
this entrance over here.
I thought, oh wonderful.

This building is really
addressing people
coming from many directions.

The one thing that I'm
finding about this,

it seems to be the
primary point of arrival
when you come into that space.

That's like center, and
that's a place of choice

when you decide to either
from here to go to the theater

or go off in the garden or
start your procession up.

It would have been very nice
if this path could have also

brought us to a common
point where everyone--

if there was a coherent
place of arrival,

which is what you seem to
be seeking in that form.
But I think both of--

or each of your forces
coming into that territory.

GUEST SPEAKER: I can
see they kind of clash.
I wasn't-- yeah.

AUDIENCE: The last comment
also relates to the theater.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.

AUDIENCE: And for me
anyway at the moment.
You said IMAX.

I think the scale of
this is too small.
GUEST SPEAKER: OK.

AUDIENCE: It's a much more
intimate, smaller space.

I don't know how many people are
in this theater, but it's not--

it's a huge screen and
they can't do as much.
So it's about something else.

It could be almost
a lecture hall,

where people are told more about
butterflies and shown things,

or it could be a movie about
movies or smaller things.

And the shape of it is
nice and intriguing.

I understand why you've done
that and bringing people
around the corner.

But when you're in
that space, think

of how that movie screen
actually plays out

and where you sit
and what you see.

And you're feeling--
you're kind of slightly
at an angle to everything.

So there's something
about, I think,

the design of
theaters and the way

that they open into
the front, whether it's

a cinema or it's movie
theater or an actual theater

that I think just the location
of the sculptural form

versus the actual how
you inhabit the space--
